overview_of_class:
This course explores the origin, composition, and classification of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks, application of laboratory characterization and basic thermodynamics to interpreting observed rock textures and mineral assemblages in terms of geological processes.

Prerequisite: EARTH 300 or consent of instructor.

Lab Section required.
name: Petrology: Evolution of Crustal and Mantle Rocks
title: WCAS EARTH 301-0-01 Petrology: Evolution of Crustal and Mantle Rocks

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course explores the origin, composition, and classification of igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks, application of laboratory characterization and basic thermodynamics to interpreting observed rock textures and mineral assemblages in terms of geological processes.

Prerequisite: EARTH 300 or consent of instructor.

Lab Section required.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisite: EARTH 300 or consent of instructor.

Lab Section required. Any scheduling conflicts for lab sections will be resolved during the first week of class, potentially allowing students to attend half of each section, or to work during the lunch break between sections, or perhaps even shifting the time of one section.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will become proficient with optical microscopes, employing polarized light to identify primary and accessory minerals, and examine crystalline textures to deduce the geologic setting of rock formation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
B.R. Frost and C.D. Frost, Essentials of Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology, 2013, Cambridge, ISBN 0174343256. Frost & Frost is available for about $50 on Amazon.

Other assigned readings will be available electronically via links on Canvas. (Several pages of additional material will be made available from H. Blatt, R.J. Tracy, and B.E. Owens, Petrology [2006], a classic, advanced, comprehensive textbook.)

Mead Composition Notebook, or similar Lab notebook.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
The following book will be used for the course, and several copies will be available in the lab. For that reason, it is only "suggested" that you purchase it. If you like to have your own copy, please purchase the following:

W.S. MacKenzie and A.E. Adams, A Color Atlas of Rocks and Minerals in Thin Section, 1994, Wiley, 0470233389. MacKenzie & Adams is available for about $30 on Amazon.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Registration for one of the 2-hour lab sections on Wednesday is required. Any scheduling conflicts for lab sections will be resolved during the first week of class, potentially allowing students to attend half of each section, or to work during the lunch break between sections, or perhaps even shifting the time of one section.
